tweets.text:
1/ Urban life is cash flow intense. Rural life is capital intense. 

( @vgr opinion per like challenge)
@vgr 2/ The culture war is real and annoying for both sides.
@vgr Rural areas are more diverse than you think. But they are  segregated physiologically, and aside from culture warriors everyone hides their ideology.

@vgr 4/ There isn’t more “community” in rural areas. It’s just different. Contact is less frequent and more intense. People you have looser connections to are more likely to help you e.g. neighbor thinks you’re a libtard ruining America but will loan you their tractor.
@vgr 5/ I should have said #1 in terms of stocks and flows because it applies to more than just money. Rural life is all about stocks, urban flows.
@vgr 6/ You’re going to become at least occasionally involved with a church whether you like it or not.
7/ Urban churches are about religion. Rural churches are primarily social institutions.
8/ It takes a while and is harder to find your people, but you can do it.
9/ The rural environment is much more holey than urban. Lots of little enclaves and pockets.
10/ Be prepared to do a lot more scheduling and planning.

8.a/ Don’t get me wrong, rural churches are also about religion but they have a huge social function.

Reposted for threading purposes
11/ There are more local businesses in urban areas. Local business exists in rural areas but mostly sustained by tourism.  Chains and mega corps are the dominant businesses.
12/ This an obvious one, but get into podcasts or audiobooks because you will be driving ALL THE TIME
13/ You are surrounded by farms but the produce at the grocery store is worse. Buy direct from the farmer.
14/ Urban to rural move requires a lot of intention. You generally have to create anything you want to happen, be it developing your land or becoming part of the community.
15/ You don’t have to worry about packages getting stolen off the porch. You do have to worry about rats eating the wiring in your car.
